summary: Daniel is a young man who finds himself on a beach on the Southern California coast, where the sky is pink and orange and palm trees are in view.
He hears a beautiful song coming from just beyond what he can see and goes to investigate.
He finds a mermaid sitting on a rock, but the sky suddenly goes black and time stands still.
He runs to the marina to find a boat so he can get to the rock, but bumps into another boat and knocks a frozen person overboard.
He jumps in to rescue them and eventually finds himself on the rock with the mermaid, but she has suddenly changed from a beautiful creature into a gray seal.
He panics and crashes the boat, knocking himself unconscious.
When he wakes up he is in a hospital and his parents are discussing sending him to rehab.
Daniel agrees, and then falls back asleep.
He wakes up again on the beach and the seal is there, singing the same song.
He jumps into the water and the seal bites him, but his skin breaks the teeth.
Daniel smiles and brings them back to the beach, and when he wakes up in the hospital again he tells his father rehab is a good idea.
explanation: The sentence states that "Daniel is a young man" but the story doesn't explicitly mention Daniel's age or that he is a "young man." This is an assumption that isn't directly supported by the text.
Daniel never actually reaches the rock with the mermaid before discovering it's a seal. Instead, he realizes it's a seal while approaching the rocks when "the mermaid got larger and decidedly gray."

The sequence of events is incorrect. In the story, Daniel rescues a frozen person who fell overboard, then continues toward the rocks in the boat, realizes the "mermaid" is actually a seal, and finally crashes into the rocks and is knocked unconscious.

The summary incorrectly states that Daniel agrees to rehab before falling back asleep, but in the story, he only tries to speak to his mother saying "Hey, mo-" before falling back asleep. He doesn't express agreement about rehab at this point.
Daniel doesn't actually agree to rehab until the very end of the story when he explicitly says "Rehab sounds great to me."
After hearing his father talk about rehab, the text only indicates that "He broke through the surface and grimaced in pain," with no mention of agreement to rehab at this point.
The summary sentence incorrectly presents events from the story. In reality, Daniel jumps into the water after the seal, and the seal whips its tail into Daniel's ribs causing him pain.
The seal biting Daniel occurs in what appears to be a dream sequence or hallucination, not in the actual physical encounter. This important context is missing from the summary.

The detail about "the teeth didn't break the skin, the skin broke the teeth" happens specifically after Daniel realizes "the dream is his" and takes control of the situation. This crucial element of Daniel gaining control in the dream state needs to be included for accuracy.
The word "teeth" is only used once and it should be used twice.
rewrites: Daniel finds himself on a beach on the Southern California coast, where the sky is pink and orange and palm trees are in view.
He jumps in to rescue them and continues toward the rock, but as he approaches, he realizes what he thought was a mermaid is actually a gray seal.
Daniel tries to speak to his mother but falls back asleep.
In his dream, he jumps into the water and when the seal bites him, his skin breaks the seal's teeth rather than the teeth breaking his skin.

summary: A man named Daniel is walking on a beach in California when he hears a beautiful song.
He follows the song and sees a mermaid sitting on a rock, waving him over.
Daniel tries to find a way to reach her, but in the process of getting a boat, he hits a frozen person and falls unconscious.
He wakes up in a hospital and falls back asleep.
In his dream, he is back on the beach with the mermaid, and the seal attacks him, causing him to wake up again.
He hears his father talking about his rehab and decides to accept it.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that Daniel saw a mermaid, when in fact what he initially perceived as a mermaid was later revealed to be a seal. This is an important factual correction to make.
Daniel doesn't hit a frozen person directly - he bumps another boat, which causes a frozen person to fall overboard, and then Daniel rescues this person.
The timing is incorrect - Daniel becomes unconscious later in the sequence of events, when he crashes the boat into rocks after realizing the mermaid is actually a seal.
The summary omits the important revelation that what Daniel thought was a mermaid turns out to be a seal.

The summary incorrectly states that Daniel was "back on the beach with the mermaid" in later scenes, when in fact he was interacting with a seal. Daniel initially mistook a seal for a mermaid, but later realized it was actually a seal.
In Daniel's subsequent dreams/experiences, he interacts with the seal (not a mermaid), and it is this seal that attacks him multiple times, causing him to wake up in the hospital.
rewrites: He follows the song and sees what he thinks is a mermaid sitting on a rock, waving him over.

Daniel tries to find a way to reach her, but in the process of getting a boat, he bumps into another boat causing a frozen person to fall overboard, and later crashes into rocks, knocking himself unconscious.
In his dream, he is back on the beach with the seal, and the seal attacks him, causing him to wake up again.

summary: Daniel is walking on a beach in Southern California when he notices a mermaid sitting on a rock singing a beautiful song.
As he gets closer to investigate, time freezes around him.
He tries to find a way to get to the rock where the mermaid is sitting.
After bumping into frozen people and boats, he makes it to the rock only to find that the mermaid has turned into a seal.
He crashes his boat and gets knocked unconscious.
He then seems to wake up multiple times, alternating between being on the beach with the seal and in the hospital.
The experiences blur together and it's unclear what is real.
In the end, after a series of chaotic and surreal events, Daniel agrees to go to rehab.
The story appears to depict a man grappling with reality and struggling with substance abuse or mental health issues.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that Daniel bumped into "boats" (plural), when he actually only bumped into a single boat.

The summary suggests that the mermaid transformed into a seal before Daniel's eyes, but the text indicates this was a case of mistaken identity. The phrase "the mermaid got larger and decidedly gray" and "For the second time that day, Daniel couldn't believe what he was seeing" shows Daniel realized what he thought was a mermaid was actually a seal all along, not that a transformation occurred.

The summary needs to be rewritten because it uses the word "seems" which introduces subjectivity or uncertainty, when the alternating pattern of Daniel waking up in different locations (beach and hospital) is objectively presented in the text.

The explanation provides clear textual evidence of the alternating wake pattern: Daniel wakes in the hospital after the crash, then on the beach with the seal, then back in the hospital, then on the beach again, then hears his parents (in the hospital), and finally wakes up in the hospital at the end.
Removing "seems" would make the sentence fully objective and more accurately represent what is factually presented in the story.

The story strongly implies Daniel has substance abuse issues through multiple pieces of evidence: his father explicitly mentioning rehab, threatening to kick him out unless he goes to rehab, and Daniel ultimately agreeing that "Rehab sounds great."

The interpretation that Daniel is "grappling with reality" is supported by textual evidence including his surreal experiences with time freezing, hallucinations, and the alternating between beach and hospital scenes.

While the story doesn't explicitly state Daniel has substance abuse issues, the summary sentence represents a reasonable interpretation based on substantial textual evidence rather than being a subjective claim.
The summary sentence could be slightly more precise in how it presents these elements.
rewrites: After bumping into a boat and rescuing a frozen person who fell overboard, he approaches the rock only to discover that what he thought was a mermaid is actually a seal.
He wakes up multiple times, alternating between being on the beach with the seal and in the hospital.
The story suggests a man experiencing altered states of consciousness who ultimately agrees to his father's demand that he attend rehab.

summary: A man is suddenly pulled into a beam of light and finds himself in a strange white room, restrained on a cold metal table.
He is met by strange figures who appear to be conducting some kind of experiment on him.
They use a strange semi-transparent instrument filled with blue liquid, and then leave abruptly.
The man finds himself back on the wet road he was standing on before, with a lollipop in his hand.
He is left to wonder what just happened and if it was all real.
explanation: The phrase "appear to be conducting some kind of experiment" is somewhat interpretive. While the text describes restraints, medical-like instruments, and procedures resembling an examination, it doesn't explicitly state that an "experiment" is taking place.
The original sentence omits that the instrument is described as "long" in the story.
The summary doesn't mention that the instrument makes a whirring sound and is brought near the narrator's ear.
The summary fails to include that the narrator experiences "a rush of cold liquid" and pain in the ear when the instrument is used.

The word "abruptly" to describe the beings' departure may be slightly subjective since the story doesn't explicitly state the manner of their departure - it only mentions they "vanished from sight" after releasing the narrator.
There are no significant reasons given for why the summary sentence needs to be rewritten. In fact, the explanation indicates that the sentence is mostly accurate.

The explanation points out only one minor potential issue: the story doesn't explicitly state the man was "standing on" the road before the abduction, though this is described as "a reasonable inference."

The explanation confirms that the sentence accurately captures two key facts from the story: that the man returned to a wet road (described as "familiar" in the story) and that he had a lollipop in his hand.
The summary incorrectly states that the character wonders about the reality of his experience, but the text doesn't mention any such wondering or questioning

The text only describes objective observations - the character looking behind and seeing nothing, as if the room never existed, and finding a lollipop in his hand - rather than any internal questioning about reality
rewrites: He is met by strange figures who use instruments on him while he is restrained.
They use a long, semi-transparent instrument filled with blue liquid, and then disappear after releasing the narrator.
The man finds himself back on the familiar wet road, with a lollipop in his hand.
After returning to the wet road, he looks behind him to find no evidence of the room or ship, as if it never existed, and discovers he's holding a lollipop.

summary: The protagonist gets abducted by aliens after drinking a gas station coke.
They wake up restrained on a table in a white room with strange figures surrounding them.
The figures use an instrument that causes the protagonist pain and discomfort.
A woman's voice scolds the protagonist for wasting the aliens' time.
The figures release the protagonist and give them a lollipop before disappearing, leaving the protagonist alone on a wet road.
explanation: The text never explicitly states that the beings are "aliens" - they are only described as "strange figures" with "large black eyes" and other non-human characteristics.
Using the term "aliens" is an interpretation rather than directly stated in the text, making it less objective than describing what's actually in the story.

The summary incorrectly identifies the strange figures as "aliens" when the original story only refers to them as "strange figures," "beings," or "things" without explicitly identifying them as aliens (though alien abduction is implied).
The summary needs to be more objective and avoid making definitive claims about the identity of these beings when the original text is more ambiguous.
rewrites: The protagonist gets pulled into the night sky by a beam of light after drinking a gas station coke, and wakes up restrained on a table surrounded by strange figures.
A woman's voice scolds the protagonist for wasting the strange figures' time.

summary: A man is abducted from his car while drinking a soda by a beam of light.
He wakes up naked and restrained on a cold metallic table inside an all-white room.
Strange alien beings attempt to insert a long instrument filled with blue liquid into his ear, causing him immense pain.
He protests and shouts at them to stop.
A female voice scolds him for wasting the aliens' time and being ridiculous.
After another painful attempt, he is suddenly released from the restraints and finds himself back on a wet road, with no sign of the alien ship or room.
However, he notices he is now holding a lollipop in his hand.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that the person was in a car when abducted, but the original story doesn't explicitly mention this - it only mentions having a gas station coke before being pulled up by light.
The explanation acknowledges that interpreting "coke" as soda is reasonable, so this part of the summary doesn't need correction.

The phrase "strange alien beings" is an interpretation rather than what's directly stated in the story, which describes them as "strange figures" with large black eyes that communicate with trilling sounds. While calling them "alien beings" is a reasonable interpretation, it goes beyond what's explicitly stated in the text.
rewrites: A person is pulled into the night sky by a beam of light shortly after drinking a gas station coke.
Strange figures attempt to insert a long instrument filled with blue liquid into his ear, causing him immense pain.

summary: Mr. Spiegel is a powerful individual who has demonstrated the ability to manipulate the space-time continuum.
He has been hired by an official's government to bring an empire to its knees without killing more than twenty to thirty million people.

The official is shocked to learn that Spiegel can do this to entire cities, continents and even planets, and is even more horrified when Spiegel reveals that he can also see the future and knows that death and destruction will be inflicted by his hands.
When the official threatens to shoot Spiegel like a rabid dog, Spiegel calmly reveals that it wouldn't matter, as he would still find someone else to conquer the official's country.
He then leaves, whistling as he goes.
explanation: The summary uses subjective interpretations of emotions ("shocked" and "horrified") rather than objectively describing the official's reaction as shown in the text.
The text shows physical signs like turning white and speaking breathlessly, which suggest strong emotions, but explicitly labeling these specific emotions goes beyond the objective evidence.

The summary incorrectly states that Spiegel would "find someone else to conquer the official's country" when in fact Spiegel said he would "walk into an office on the other side of the planet and offer someone to conquer your country for them." The distinction is that Spiegel would offer his services to help someone else conquer the country, not just find someone else to do it.
The summary describes Spiegel as responding "calmly," but the story doesn't explicitly describe his demeanor this way, though his response does appear matter-of-fact.
rewrites: The official turns white upon learning that Spiegel can do this to entire cities, continents and even planets, and responds breathlessly when Spiegel reveals that he can also see the future and knows that death and destruction will be inflicted by his hands.

When the official threatens to shoot Spiegel "like a rabid dog," Spiegel reveals that it wouldn't matter, as he would simultaneously appear elsewhere and offer to help someone conquer the official's country.

summary: Spiegel is a man with the ability to cause destruction on a massive scale.
He has been hired by a government to bring down an empire, but he warns that his methods will result in the deaths of millions.
Spiegel claims to be able to see the future and reveals that he plans to continue causing destruction on an even greater scale.
When the official he is speaking with threatens to shoot him, Spiegel reveals that he is not loyal to any one country and will simply offer his services to someone else.
He leaves, whistling happily, while the official is left contemplating the destructive power of Spiegel's abilities.
explanation: The summary states that the character whistles "happily," but the original text only mentions whistling without specifying the emotional state. This adds a subjective interpretation not present in the source text.

The summary claims the official is "left contemplating the destructive power of Spiegel's abilities," but the original text doesn't describe the official's thoughts after Spiegel leaves. This is an unsupported inference about what the character is thinking.
rewrites: He leaves, whistling as he walks down the corridor, while the official remains behind.

summary: The story is about a man named Spiegel who has powerful abilities, including the ability to manipulate space, time, and the future.
He meets with an official from a government, claiming that he can help the government conquer an empire and bring it to its knees, with a limited amount of bloodshed, around 20-30 million deaths.
Spiegel boasts about his powerful abilities, saying he can inflict destruction on entire cities, continents, planets, and eventually even star systems.
He claims to know the future, in which he foresees death and destruction brought about in part by his own hands.
When the official threatens to shoot Spiegel, Spiegel claims that this would not stop him, as he would simply appear elsewhere and make a deal with another country.
The story depicts Spiegel as a menacing, power-hungry figure who cares little for human life.
His extreme powers and disregard for morality pose a grave threat to humanity.
explanation: The summary uses subjective, interpretive terms like "menacing," "power-hungry," and "cares little for human life" to characterize Spiegel rather than objective facts directly stated in the text.

While the story shows Spiegel's actions (casually discussing millions of deaths, giggling about it, and speaking about future destruction), the summary should focus on these objective behaviors rather than making judgments about his character.

The summary sentence includes a judgment by characterizing Spiegel as a "grave threat," but this is not explicitly stated in the original text. The text only mentions that Spiegel speaks about causing death and destruction, but doesn't directly label him as a grave threat.
rewrites: In the story, Spiegel speaks casually about killing millions of people, giggles when discussing destruction, and states he will cause death and destruction in the future while showing little concern for human casualties.
Spiegel speaks of his powers and future plans that involve death and destruction for humanity.

summary: The rescue team went into a cave to rescue a man who had fallen down a vertical shaft.
The team took turns talking to him over a radio, providing him with updates and encouragement.
When they finally extracted him, he thanked them for rescuing him and apologized for losing their radio.
When the team was about to leave, the radio came to life again and the same voice asked when they were coming to get him.
explanation: The original summary mentions that the team provided "encouragement" to the man, but this is not explicitly stated in the story. This is an interpretation rather than a fact directly supported by the text.

While the summary correctly states that the team took turns talking to him over a radio and provided updates, it should be more specific about the content of those updates (that they had to request special equipment be flown in for the rescue) to accurately reflect what's in the story.
The summary doesn't mention the man's unusual behavior of introducing himself to people he had supposedly been speaking with for days, which is a key detail from the story.

The summary incorrectly states that the man thanked the team for rescuing him, but the story only describes him hugging team members and introducing himself, without specifically mentioning him thanking them.
The summary incorrectly states that "the team was about to leave" when this detail is not mentioned anywhere in the original story.

The summary inaccurately describes the voice on the radio as "the same voice" when the original story specifically states it was "a voice identical to the man standing in front of them" - an important distinction that creates the supernatural/mysterious element of the story.
rewrites: The team took turns talking to him over a radio, providing him with updates about the rescue operation.
When they finally extracted him, he was ecstatic, hugged each team member, introduced himself, and apologized for losing their radio.
The rescue team looked at each other, just as the radio flared to life and a voice identical to the man standing in front of them asked when they were coming to get him.

summary: A rescue team goes into a narrow cave to find a participant who had fallen down a blocked-off section.
They drop a radio down to him and start a multiple day rescue operation, during which they take turns speaking with the man who remains surprisingly calm.
When they finally extract him, he apologizes for losing their radio, but before they can say anything, the radio flares to life with the same voice asking when they will come to get him.
The team realizes that the man they rescued was not the one who had fallen down the shaft, and they wonder who they had actually been talking to.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that the team "realizes" something, but the original story doesn't explicitly mention any realization by the team.
The summary incorrectly states that the team "wonders who they were talking to," but the original story doesn't explicitly describe the team wondering this.
The summary attributes specific thoughts and mental states to the team that aren't directly stated in the text, which is an interpretation rather than what's explicitly described in the story.
A more accurate summary should describe what actually happened (the radio activating with a voice identical to the rescued man) without assuming the team's thoughts or reactions.
Using the term "wonder" implies a holiday spirit which invokes a different context than the story describes.
rewrites: The radio flares to life with a voice identical to the rescued man's asking when they're coming to get him, contradicting the rescued man's claim that he never used the radio.

summary: A rescue team enters a cave in order to save a man who has fallen down a narrow vertical shaft.
After days of work, they are able to extract him from the shaft.
However, once he is out, he proceeds to hug and introduce himself to each member of the team, even though they had spoken extensively with him over the radio during the multi-day rescue operation.
Perplexed, the team then realizes that the man never actually had the radio, and that the voice they heard was someone else trapped further down the shaft.
The man they rescued had merely apologized for losing the radio when they first dropped it down, but in fact it had fallen past him to someone trapped below.
The story ends with the radio flaring to life again and the voice of the other trapped person asking when the rescue team will come for him.
explanation: The summary states that the team "realizes" something, but this is an interpretation rather than what's explicitly stated in the original story. The story doesn't explicitly mention the team realizing anything.
The summary presents an inference (that they were speaking to someone else) as a fact, when this is a conclusion the reader might draw rather than something directly stated in the text.

A more objective summary should describe what was revealed in the story (the man apologizing for losing the radio, then an identical voice coming from the radio) rather than attributing specific realizations to the characters.

The summary sentence makes an inference that there was "someone trapped below" which is not explicitly stated in the original story. While this is strongly implied by the radio communication at the end (a voice identical to the rescued man's asking when they were coming to get him), it remains an interpretation rather than an explicitly stated fact.

The original story only directly states that: the rescued man apologized for losing the radio, explained it fell down a hole when dropped, said he never used it, and then at the end, a voice identical to the rescued man's came from the radio.
rewrites: Perplexed, the team learns that the man never actually had the radio, and that the voice they heard was someone else trapped further down the shaft.
The man they rescued apologized for losing the radio when they first dropped it down, explaining that it had hit his hand and fallen further down the shaft, and that he had never been able to use it.

summary: Destiny visits her best friend Heaven's house on her way to the playground and is shocked when Heaven's father leads her to the basement.
When the door slams shut, Destiny is plunged into darkness and finds Heaven on the floor.
Heaven reassures her that they can now play in the basement together.
explanation: The summary incorrectly identifies the man who answers the door as Heaven's father, when the story explicitly states "She wasn't sure if this was Heaven's dad or not" and only refers to him as "a man in a dirty shirt."
The summary incorrectly describes Destiny as being "shocked" when led to the basement, whereas the story actually describes her as being "unsure."

The summary incorrectly states that Destiny "finds Heaven on the floor," but the text only indicates that Destiny's hands felt cold flesh and her fingers caught in a tangle of hair, implying Heaven's presence but not explicitly stating she was "on the floor."
The summary needs to be more precise and objective, sticking to what is explicitly stated in the text rather than making assumptions about Heaven's exact position.

The word "reassures" is subjective and implies Heaven is providing comfort in a normal way, when the context suggests something much more sinister. The story strongly implies Heaven is dead (through descriptions of "cold flesh" and Destiny's "fingers caught in a tangle of hair"), making "reassures" inappropriate for this supernatural/horror context.
A more objective description would maintain Heaven's exact wording ("It's OK. Now we can play down here together.") without characterizing it as reassurance.
rewrites: Destiny visits her best friend Heaven's house on her way to the playground and is unsure when a man, possibly Heaven's father, leads her to the basement.
When the door slams shut, Destiny is plunged into darkness and her hands touch cold flesh and hair before she hears Heaven's voice.
Heaven tells her that now they can play down there together.

summary: Destiny and Heaven are best friends who often play together at the park.
Destiny notices some strange changes in Heaven's behavior, such as wearing the same clothes for a week and no longer being friends with other kids.
When Destiny goes to Heaven's house to ask her to play, a man answers the door and leads her to the basement where Heaven has been playing for a week.
The man shoves Destiny down the stairs, leaving her trapped in the basement with Heaven, who says they can now play together.
explanation: The summary presents the man's claim that Heaven "has been playing down there all week" as a fact, when in the story this is only what the man claims, not necessarily the truth.
The story actually suggests something sinister has happened to Heaven, and the man is lying to lure Destiny into the basement.
Evidence in the story contradicts the man's claim, as when Destiny falls, she feels "cold flesh" and "a tangle of hair," suggesting Heaven may be dead rather than playing.
rewrites: When Destiny goes to Heaven's house to ask her to play, a man answers the door and leads her to the basement, claiming Heaven has been playing there all week.

summary: Destiny goes to visit her best friend Heaven at her house.
Heaven's father lets Destiny into the house and leads her down to the basement, claiming Heaven has been playing down there all week.
Once Destiny reaches the bottom of the stairs, she discovers Heaven's dead body in the dark basement.
Heaven's ghost then whispers to Destiny that now they can play together in the basement.
The story suggests that Heaven's father was responsible for her death and lured Destiny into the basement to harm or kill her as well.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that "Heaven's father" lets Destiny in, but the story only mentions "a man in a dirty shirt" and does not confirm his identity. The story explicitly states "She wasn't sure if this was Heaven's dad or not," meaning the man's relationship to Heaven is uncertain.
It is very unlikely Heaven has a father since she is a ghost.

The summary incorrectly states that Destiny discovers "Heaven's dead body," but the text only mentions that she felt "cold flesh" and "a tangle of hair" without explicitly identifying whose body it is.
The text doesn't definitively confirm that Heaven is dead or that the body Destiny touches belongs to Heaven, only strongly implying something has happened to Heaven.

The summary states "Heaven's ghost" is speaking to Destiny, but the original story only mentions "Heaven's voice" without explicitly confirming it's a ghost. The summary presents a supernatural interpretation as fact when the story itself doesn't definitively establish this.
The summary incorrectly states that the man is Heaven's father, when the story explicitly says "She wasn't sure if this was Heaven's dad or not," leaving his identity uncertain.

The summary assumes the man is responsible for Heaven's death, which is implied but not directly stated in the story. The story only shows that Heaven appears to be dead (Destiny feels "cold flesh" and "a tangle of hair") and that the man knows about Heaven's condition.

The summary claims the man intends to kill Destiny in the same way he killed Heaven, but while his actions are threatening (pushing her down stairs and locking her in), his specific intent to kill her is not explicitly stated in the story, only implied.
rewrites: A man, who may or may not be Heaven's father, lets Destiny into the house and leads her down to the basement, claiming Heaven has been playing down there all week.
Once Destiny reaches the bottom of the stairs, she feels cold flesh and hair in the dark basement, and then hears Heaven's voice.
Destiny hears Heaven's voice whisper that now they can play together down there.
The story implies that a man in Heaven's house trapped Destiny in the basement where Heaven appears to be dead, suggesting sinister intentions.

summary: A man spends his day dreaming of the beautiful woman he will be seeing later that night.
When she arrives, he guides her to the dining room, where he has prepared a meal with a single plate.
He then pulls out a knife and stabs her in the chest, taking her heart out and placing it on the plate.
He feasts on it, savoring every bite, and then rests until he can find a new heart to call his own.
The narrator is excited to have found a Valentine, and spends the day dreaming about her.
He prepares a meal for her, but when she arrives, he stabs her and carves out her heart to eat.
He reflects that he will find a new love and heart to call his own in the future.
The story follows an unnamed protagonist who dreams of finding love on Valentine's Day.
He finds a woman who says "yes" when he asks her to be his valentine.
He spends the day dreaming about her and preparing a romantic dinner for her.
When she arrives, he stabs her to death and carves out her heart.
He places her heart on his plate of pasta and eats it, staining everything red with her blood.
The protagonist views this murder and cannibalism as an expression of love, and the story ends by saying he will find a new love and repeat the process again next year.
The story depicts a disturbing and sinister take on the themes of romance and love.
explanation: The summary states the protagonist "dreams of finding love" which is interpretive rather than what's explicitly stated in the text. The story only shows he wants someone to say "yes" to being his valentine.

The summary misrepresents the protagonist's intentions by framing them as romantic when the story reveals he has a disturbing pattern of killing women and eating their hearts, suggesting his concept of "love" is twisted and not genuine love in the conventional sense.
A more accurate summary should focus on what's explicitly stated in the text rather than making interpretive characterizations of the protagonist's motivations.

The phrase "preparing a romantic dinner for her" contains subjective interpretation. The story mentions preparing pasta with white sauce and placing a white rose on the plate, but doesn't explicitly describe the dinner as "romantic." The summary should be more objective and stick to the facts presented in the story.
The words "disturbing" and "sinister" are subjective judgment words that represent an interpretation rather than objective facts from the text.
Using evaluative language like "disturbing" and "sinister" imposes a value judgment that may not be shared by all readers.
A more objective summary should focus on factual elements without evaluative language.
rewrites: The story follows an unnamed protagonist who seeks a valentine on Valentine's Day.
He spends the day dreaming about her and preparing a dinner for her.
The story presents an unconventional interpretation of romance and love themes that involves murder and cannibalism.

summary: The narrator is visiting a cemetery, and has a strange gift where they can hear the voices of the dead.
As they explore, they come across several graves that are speaking to them, including one belonging to a baby, a man who was prejudiced against people of color, and a beloved mother.
The narrator talks to their mother's grave and reminisces, and finds that even in death, their mother still has plenty of wit and humor.
explanation: The summary incorrectly characterizes the mother's response from the grave as showing "wit and humor" when her actual words are harsh and accusatory: "You brat! I took care of you and your brother! I gave you your own closet. But you scratched it like a cat! You! You didn't know how to wash in the tub, so I showed you how!"
The narrator's response to the mother's words ("At least you won't hurt me or Hector anymore") suggests an abusive relationship rather than the mother having "wit and humor" in death.
The characterization of the mother's words is subjective rather than objective, and doesn't accurately reflect what's shown in the text.
rewrites: The narrator talks to their mother's grave and reminisces, but their mother's response is accusatory, prompting the narrator to remark that at least she can't hurt them or their brother anymore.

summary: The protagonist hates going to cemeteries because they have the ability to hear the dead and the dead can hear them too.
They walk through the cemetery and hear various voices and stories from the graves.
They eventually make it to their mother's grave and have a conversation with her, reminiscing about their past.
The story ends with the protagonist feeling comforted by their mother's voice.
explanation: The summary incorrectly portrays the interaction at the mother's grave as positive "reminiscing" when it was actually negative, with the mother being harsh and accusatory.
The summary misses that the protagonist laughed at the mother's response and said "You're telling a different story, mom," suggesting disagreement about the past.
The summary fails to capture the ending's implication that the protagonist feels relief that the mother can no longer hurt them or their brother.
Overall, the summary presents the grave interaction as more positive and mutual than it actually was in the text.

The summary incorrectly characterizes the protagonist's reaction as finding comfort in hearing the mother's voice, when the text actually shows the protagonist expressing relief that the mother "won't hurt me or Hector anymore," indicating the end of harm rather than comfort.
The protagonist's laughter is not from comfort but appears to be a reaction to the discrepancy between their memories and what the mother is saying ("You're telling a different story, mom").
The mother's voice is described as accusatory ("You brat!"), which contradicts the notion that hearing it would be comforting to the protagonist.
rewrites: They eventually make it to their mother's grave and speak to her, but her response is accusatory, bringing up negative aspects of their past.
The story ends with the protagonist laughing at their mother's accusations and expressing relief that she can no longer hurt them or their brother.

summary: The narrator has the unusual ability to hear the voices of the dead when visiting cemeteries.
The narrator finds cemeteries unpleasant to visit because of this ability.
While walking through a cemetery and hearing various voices from graves, the narrator arrives at the grave of the narrator's mother, marked by an angel statue.
The narrator speaks to the mother's spirit and reminisces about memories of her.
Despite the strange ability, the narrator finds comfort communicating with the mother's spirit.
The story suggests the narrator has a complex relationship with the supernatural ability to hear the dead.
explanation: The summary claims the narrator finds "comfort" in communicating with their mother's spirit, but this interpretation is not directly supported by the text. While the narrator laughs and smiles at the mother's whisper, they also mention "strong emotions coming" and needing to "gather courage" to speak to her.

The ending suggests a complicated relationship with the mother who may have been abusive, as evidenced by the line "At least you won't hurt me or Hector anymore," which contradicts the idea that the communication is comforting.
The claim about finding "comfort" is a subjective interpretation rather than an objective summary of what's explicitly stated in the text.
rewrites: The narrator communicates with the mother's spirit, laughing and smiling at her whispered response, though the story suggests their relationship was complicated.

summary: Casey, a struggling artist, becomes a housekeeper for Meredith, a 77-year-old woman to make ends meet.
Meredith offers Casey $1000 to paint her as she imagines she would have looked at 30.
After completing the painting, Casey is asked to sign it as "Reynaldo," which she refuses to do, causing Meredith to ruin the painting.
Stubborn Casey demands payment, leaves, and cuts ties with Meredith.
She later learns that "Reynaldo" was Meredith's cat, who supposedly painted better than Casey, hurting her pride.
In financial struggles again, Casey discovers several paintings by Reynaldo on the walls of a coffee shop, only to regret her decision.
She laments her missed opportunity of getting paid well for painting due to her prideful behavior.
explanation: The summary incorrectly characterizes Casey as "stubborn," which is a subjective judgment not present in the original story.
The word "demands" is too strong compared to the original text, which only states that Casey "asked to be paid."
The rest of the sentence is factually accurate - Casey did leave and did not return to clean Meredith's house.
The summary presents the subjective judgment that Reynaldo painted better than Casey as a fact, when in the story this is clearly the grocery store manager's opinion, not an established fact.
The summary states that Casey's pride was hurt, but the story only mentions that she was "angry" after the interaction, not explicitly that her pride was hurt.
rewrites: Casey asks for payment, leaves, and cuts ties with Meredith.
She later learns that "Reynaldo" was Meredith's beloved cat, who according to the grocery store manager, was a far better painter than Casey would ever be.

summary: In the story "The Painter Cat," Casey, a struggling artist, takes a job as a maid for an elderly woman named Meredith to make ends meet.
One day, Meredith offers Casey $1,000 to paint a portrait of her as a 30-year-old woman.
Casey accepts the offer and works hard to create the painting, taking artistic liberties to make Meredith appear youthful and beautiful.
When the painting is finished, Meredith insists that Casey sign the name "Reynaldo" instead of her own.
Casey refuses and signs her own name, causing Meredith to become distraught and destroy the painting.
Casey leaves with the money but feels confused about the situation.
Later, Casey learns from a grocery store manager that Reynaldo was actually Meredith's beloved cat, who was a better painter than Casey.
Weeks later, struggling financially again, Casey sees several portraits of Meredith displayed in a coffee bar, all signed by "Reynaldo."
She discovers that Meredith is the heir to a whiskey brand fortune and that the paintings were created by her cat.
In the end, Casey realizes that her pride and refusal to follow Meredith's request cost her the opportunity to earn more money and left her in a worse situation than before.
explanation: The summary presents the manager's subjective opinion about Reynaldo's painting abilities as an objective fact, when in the story it's clearly the manager's personal assessment that "Reynaldo had been Meredith's beloved cat and was a far better painter than Casey would ever be."

The story shows this is the manager's opinion rather than an established fact, as evidenced by his personal judgment that he "had seen the painting with his own eyes and thought it was a hideous disaster."
The summary incorrectly presents information as a discovery that Casey made, when in the original story this information was actually told to Casey at the coffee shop.

The summary states as objective fact that the paintings were made by a cat belonging to an heiress, whereas the original text presents this as information Casey "was told" - not necessarily confirming its truth.
rewrites: Later, Casey learns from a grocery store manager that Reynaldo was actually Meredith's beloved cat, who the manager claimed was a better painter than Casey.
She is told that Meredith is the heir to a whiskey brand fortune and that the paintings were created by her cat.

summary: Casey, a struggling artist, reluctantly takes a job as a maid for an elderly woman named Meredith.
One day, Meredith asks Casey to paint a portrait of her as if she were 30 years old, and promises to pay her $1000.
While painting, Casey takes creative liberties and signs her own name on the painting.
Meredith becomes upset and destroys the painting, leading Casey to leave and demand payment.
Later, Casey discovers that Meredith's cat, Reynaldo, is actually the talented painter behind the portraits.
Casey regrets not following Meredith's instructions and losing out on the opportunity to make money through her art.
explanation: The original sentence incorrectly suggests that Casey left and demanded payment as a direct reaction to Meredith destroying the painting.
The correct sequence in the story is that Casey knocked on Meredith's door, apologized, and asked to be paid before leaving, showing she attempted reconciliation first.
The summary misrepresents the causal relationship between events by omitting Casey's attempt to apologize before requesting payment.
The story doesn't definitively establish that Meredith's cat Reynaldo actually painted the portraits - this could be what people believe or what Meredith claimed.
The summary should reflect what Casey learns about the portraits rather than stating the cat's authorship as a definitive fact.
The story suggests Meredith wanted Casey to sign her painting as "Reynaldo" to maintain the narrative about the cat being the artist.
rewrites: Meredith becomes upset and destroys the painting, after which Casey apologizes and asks for payment before leaving.
Later, Casey learns that Meredith's cat, Reynaldo, is credited as the painter behind portraits of Meredith displayed in a coffee shop.

summary: The story is about the author's mother, who is now old and suffers from memory problems.
This happened after an accident when she stepped off a sidewalk curb and shattered her shoulder, which led to her being diagnosed with osteoporosis.
After this, her health degraded over the years and she became forgetful, even forgetting the birthdays of her children.
The author, saddened and nostalgic, wanted to give her a meaningful gift for Christmas, and recalled her mother once speaking about how she used to love eating honeycombs as a child.
The author goes on a two-day journey to separate bee farms to acquire jars of honey with combs in them.
When he hints at the gift, asking his mother if she remembers eating honeycombs, she gives him a blank stare and denies having ever done so.
They realize her memory is rapidly deteriorating.
explanation: The summary incorrectly suggests that the accident caused the mother to develop osteoporosis, when in fact she already had osteoporosis before the accident. According to the story, the accident merely led to the discovery of her pre-existing condition.

The correct sequence of events is: (1) the mother already had osteoporosis (unknown to her), (2) she fell and shattered her shoulder, and (3) this accident led to the discovery/diagnosis of her osteoporosis.
The summary states the author is "nostalgic," but this emotion isn't explicitly stated in the text, making it an interpretation rather than a fact from the story.

While the author being "saddened" is supported (they mention being "so saddened about the Great Forgetting"), the combination of "saddened and nostalgic" represents an interpretation of the author's emotional state rather than directly stated information.
The rest of the sentence accurately represents the factual content about the author wanting to give their mother a meaningful gift based on her childhood honeycomb story.

The summary incorrectly states "two-day journey" when the original text specifies "no fewer than two days tracking down and purchasing honeycomb," indicating it was at least two days, not exactly two days.
The summary uses the vague phrase "separate bee farms" instead of the more specific details from the original text: "three different bee apiaries in two different states."

The summary refers to "jars of honey with combs" which is less precise than the original text's "six separate quarts of honey with combs in them," missing both the quantity (six) and the specific measurement (quarts).

The original sentence incorrectly implies a shared realization between the author and their mother about the memory deterioration, when the text only shows the author observing this decline, not the mother acknowledging it.

The text provides evidence that only the author notices the deterioration, with phrases like "The differences are noticeable now almost daily" and "The severity of the memory problems became more noticeable every week I returned."
rewrites: Three years ago she had an accident when she stepped off a sidewalk curb and shattered her shoulder, which was how she discovered she had osteoporosis.
The author wanted to give her a meaningful gift for Christmas after hearing her mother speak about how she used to love eating honeycombs as a child.
The author spent no fewer than two days tracking down and purchasing six separate quarts of honey with combs from three different bee apiaries in two different states.
The author observes that her memory is rapidly deteriorating.

summary: In this poignant story, the narrator reflects on their mother's rapid decline in health and memory over the past three years.
Once vibrant and active, the mother's life changed dramatically after a series of accidents that revealed her osteoporosis.
Confined to a recliner and struggling with memory issues, she forgot important birthdays, including the narrator's and their father's.
One day, the mother reminisced about her childhood, recalling how she and her sisters would enjoy eating honeycombs, a rare treat at the time.
Inspired by this memory, the narrator went to great lengths to acquire six quarts of honey with combs as a special Christmas gift for their mother, knowing it might be her last Christmas.
However, when the narrator tried to remind their mother about the honeycomb memory, she had no recollection of it and even found the idea unappealing.
The story concludes on a bittersweet note, highlighting the impact of memory loss on the mother-child relationship and the narrator's efforts to bring joy to their mother during a difficult time.
explanation: The word "poignant" is subjective and represents an emotional judgment or interpretation rather than an objective fact from the text.
While the story describes a sad situation, labeling it as "poignant" reflects the summarizer's personal interpretation rather than information explicitly stated in the text.

The phrase "bittersweet note" is somewhat subjective as it's an emotional characterization, though it does accurately reflect the contrast between the sad reality (mother not remembering) and the loving intentions of the narrator.

The rest of the sentence about "highlighting the impact of memory loss" and "efforts to bring joy" are considered acceptable as they are fair interpretations of what the story demonstrates rather than subjective claims.
Only a minimal edit is needed to make the sentence slightly more objective.
rewrites: In this story, the narrator reflects on their mother's rapid decline in health and memory over the past three years.

The story concludes with the mother unable to recall the memory that inspired the narrator's gift, highlighting the impact of memory loss on the mother-child relationship and the narrator's efforts to bring joy to their mother during a difficult time.

summary: A woman's mother has aged and suffered from multiple injuries, causing her to lose her independence and vibrant personality.
As her memory problems worsen, her daughter plans to give her a special gift - honeycombs that she used to enjoy as a child but has forgotten about.
This will be the mother's last Christmas, making the gift even more meaningful.
explanation: The summary incorrectly identifies the narrator as the mother's daughter, when the story doesn't explicitly state the narrator's gender. The narrator could be a son rather than a daughter.

The summary incorrectly presents the mother's last Christmas as an established fact, when in the original text it is actually presented as the narrator's belief or expectation ("I know this will be my mom's last Christmas").
The summary should be revised to clarify that this is the narrator's perspective rather than an objective certainty.
rewrites: As her memory problems worsen, her child plans to give her a special gift - honeycombs that she used to enjoy as a child but has forgotten about.
The narrator believes this will be the mother's last Christmas, making the gift even more meaningful.

summary: The storyteller shares a chilling childhood experience that occurred when he was 13 and spent most of his time playing video games in his parent's basement.
The basement is described as "L" shaped, with the television and gaming console in the long part and a fridge around the back corner in the shorter part.
One day while playing Halo with noise-cancelling headphones, he hears a loud noise from behind him and turns around to find a beer mug on the floor near the fridge.
The mug was originally part of a display atop the fridge, featuring a neon sign and identical mugs on either side.
He shrugs off this strange occurrence and continues his game.
A week later, the same scenario repeats.
The loud noise, the beer mug on the floor, a distance away from the fridge.
This time he is terrified, turns off his game, and bolts upstairs, feeling a sense of being watched.

The next day he investigates the scene and realizes that the dust layer atop the fridge is perfectly undisturbed where the mug sits, indicating it did not slide off, but was picked straight up and thrown.
This realization sends the storyteller into horror, as he swears that on both occasions, he was the only one at home.
explanation: The phrase "chilling childhood experience" is subjective and represents an emotional judgment rather than an objective description of the events in the story.
The summary incorrectly states just "Halo" when the original story specifically mentions "Halo 3"
The summary describes the headphones simply as "headphones" without mentioning they were "Turtle Beach headphones" that "play sound through them"

The summary oversimplifies the sequence of events after hearing the noise - it states he "turned around" and found the mug, but the original story includes additional steps: he called out "Mom?" first, then got up and walked around the corner before finding the mug

The summary correctly captures that there was a "loud noise" (matching the story's "loud bang") and that the mug was found "near the fridge" (consistent with the story's "about 3 feet from the fridge")

The summary sentence uses present tense ("shrugs") while the original story uses past tense ("shrugged"). Since the rest of the summary is in past tense, it would be more consistent to use past tense throughout.
rewrites: The storyteller shares a disturbing childhood experience that occurred when he was 13 and spent most of his time playing video games in his parent's basement.

One day while playing Halo 3 with Turtle Beach headphones that played game sounds, he hears a loud bang from behind him and after investigating, finds a beer mug on the floor about 3 feet from the fridge.
He shrugged off this strange occurrence and continued his game.

summary: In this story, a 13-year-old boy experiences a series of eerie events while playing video games in his parents' finished basement.
On two separate occasions, a week apart, the boy hears a loud bang behind him while wearing noise-cancelling headphones.
Each time, he discovers that a decorative beer mug from a display on top of the fridge has fallen to the floor, landing several feet away without breaking.
The first incident leaves the boy confused, but he shrugs it off and returns the mug to its original position.
However, when the same thing happens a week later, the boy becomes terrified, feeling as if something is watching him from the darkness.
He runs upstairs, unable to shake the feeling of being watched.

The next morning, the boy investigates the top of the fridge and notices that the fallen mug has left a perfect circular outline in the dust, suggesting that it had been picked up and thrown rather than simply falling or sliding off on its own.
This realization fills the boy with an overwhelming sense of fear.
Throughout the story, the boy emphasizes that he was home alone during both incidents, adding to the mysterious and unsettling nature of the events.
explanation: The headphones were Turtle Beach headphones, not specifically "noise-cancelling" headphones. They were described as "the type of headphones that play sound through them" and that "you really can't hear anything going on in the real world around you until you take them off."
The sounds were described as "a loud bang" in the first incident and "BANG! CLINK! CLINK!" in the second incident, not just "loud noises" as the summary suggests.
The summary states the mug "has fallen to the floor," which implies a natural fall, but the story suggests the mug was actually picked up and thrown.
The summary omits specific distance measurements mentioned in the story (3 feet the first time, 5 feet the second time).

The second part of the sentence "adding to the mysterious and unsettling nature of the events" is subjective rather than factual, as it characterizes the events as "mysterious and unsettling" and makes an inference about how being alone contributes to this quality.

While the interpretation about the events being mysterious and unsettling is reasonable based on the narrator's described feelings of fear and confusion, it's better to state just the facts in a summary.

The first part of the sentence is factual and directly supported by the text, as the narrator explicitly states "I'm home alone after school" before both incidents and "On both occasions I was the only one home, trust me, I checked."
rewrites: On two separate occasions, a week apart, the boy hears a loud bang behind him while wearing Turtle Beach headphones that block outside sounds.
Each time, he discovers that a decorative beer mug from a display on top of the fridge is on the floor, landing three feet away the first time and five feet away the second time, without breaking.
Throughout the story, the boy emphasizes that he was home alone during both incidents.

summary: The narrator, who was 13 at the time, was playing video games in their parents' basement when they heard a loud bang behind them.
They turned around and found a beer mug on the ground, which had been part of a display on top of the fridge.
A week later, the same thing happened again, and the mug was found even farther away from the fridge.
The narrator became terrified and didn't go back into the basement for the rest of the day.
The next day, they investigated and found that the dust on top of the fridge had been disturbed in a circular pattern, as if the mug had been picked up and thrown.
The narrator was alone both times and could not find a rational explanation for what happened.
The narrator has the ability to see and hear ghosts, which was fun as a child but becomes torturous later in life.
After witnessing a heart-wrenching scenario with a ghost and a stray dog, he checks himself into an hospital/asylum for some solace.
The hospital appears serene with friendly nurses and patients, and the narrator feels peaceful.
After several days, he is awakened by a police officer who informs him that the hospital has been closed for years.
The story ends with the narrator's silence being shattered.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states "for some solace" as the explicit reason for checking into the hospital, when this motivation is only implied. The text shows the narrator seeking relief from seeing ghosts, saying "I need to check myself in" and telling the doctor "I just want them to leave me alone so I can rest."
There's a grammatical error in the original summary - it should use "a hospital" rather than "an hospital."

While the summary describes the scene as "heart-wrenching," the original text uses "gut-wrenching" to describe the ghost's screams and mentions "empty tears streaming down his face," so this characterization is supported but uses slightly different wording than the original.
rewrites: After witnessing a distressing scene with a ghost and a stray dog, the narrator checks into a hospital/asylum seeking relief from seeing ghosts.

summary: In this haunting story, the narrator is a person who has the ability to see and hear ghosts, which they initially enjoyed as a child but now find to be a curse.
The ghosts constantly haunt the narrator, preventing them from finding peace and rest.
One day, after witnessing a particularly distressing scene involving a ghost and a stray dog, the narrator decides to check themselves into an asylum in hopes of finding solace.
At the asylum, the narrator is greeted by a caring staff and a gentle doctor who promises to keep the ghosts at bay.

The narrator spends their days in a peaceful haze, occasionally interacting with other patients and enjoying the silence within the walls of the asylum, despite the presence of numerous ghosts outside the fence.
However, the story takes a chilling turn when the narrator is awakened by a police officer who informs them that the hospital has been closed for years.
This revelation shatters the narrator's illusion of peace, leaving them falling through the air as the silence around them is shattered.
The ending suggests that the narrator's experiences at the asylum were either a delusion or a supernatural occurrence, leaving the reader to ponder the true nature of the narrator's reality.
explanation: The explanation confirms that the sentence accurately describes the narrator's ability to see and hear ghosts, which is explicitly stated in the story with quotes like "being able to see and hear the dead is nothing but a curse" and "When I was younger, I thought it was fun. Like a game that only I could play."

The explanation notes that while the word "haunting" could be considered subjective as an evaluation of the story's tone, it is actually a reasonable characterization given the supernatural content and disturbing revelation at the end of the story.

The summary should reflect that the positive descriptions of the staff (the "lovely" front desk woman with a "heart-shaped face" who "smiled" and "greeted warmly," the nurse with "hair the color of turmeric" and feet "almost seeming to dance," and the doctor with "eyes shining like jade fire," "long, graceful fingers," voice "humming like the strings of a lute," "gentle smile," and "soft hand") are from the narrator's perspective rather than objective facts.
The sensory and positive language used in these descriptions suggests the narrator perceives the staff as caring and the doctor as gentle, which should be reflected in the summary.
The doctor's explicit promise "I'll keep the ghosts from bothering you" supports the interpretation of the staff as caring, but the summary should make clear this is the narrator's perception.

While the original summary sentence is a reasonable interpretation, it needs to be more objective by explicitly tying these impressions to the narrator's perception rather than presenting them as objective facts.

The explanation doesn't actually provide reasons why the summary sentence needs to be rewritten. It acknowledges that the sentence is mostly objective, with only the word "chilling" potentially being subjective, but even that word is described as accurately reflecting the nature of the revelation in the story context.
The explanation seems to be preparing to offer a more objective alternative wording, but doesn't complete this thought or provide specific criticisms of the original sentence.
rewrites: In this story, the narrator is a person who has the ability to see and hear ghosts, which they initially enjoyed as a child but now find to be a curse.
At the asylum, the narrator perceives a welcoming staff and a doctor who promises to keep the ghosts from bothering them.
However, the story takes a turn when the narrator is awakened by a police officer who informs them that the hospital has been closed for years.

summary: The protagonist, who can see and hear ghosts, checks into an asylum in an attempt to escape their constant presence.
With the help of a kind doctor, they find peace and rest.
However, when they wake up, they are told that the asylum has been closed for years, leaving their current state of peacefulness a mystery.
explanation: The doctor is described with physical attributes suggesting gentleness (long graceful fingers, soft hand) and a comforting presence (voice humming like strings of a lute, gentle smile, reassuring words about keeping ghosts away), but explicitly labeling her as "kind" is subjective rather than directly stated in the text.

The summary should acknowledge that the protagonist does find peace and rest in the asylum, as supported by direct quotes: "inside those walls, there was only beautiful silence" and "Most days, I sleep. I have a lifetime of rest to catch up on."
rewrites: At the asylum, they experience peace and rest after a doctor promises to keep the ghosts away.

summary: The protagonist, who is usually agitated by loud sounds, experiences an unusually strong reaction to noise while staying at a cousin's house in the forest.
Their reaction to noise escalates from annoyance to uncontrollable aggression, leading them to kill a loud bird outside in a sudden fit of rage.
Later, when their cousin yells at them for ripping a ringing telephone out of the wall, the protagonist impulsively kills their cousin.
They note a disturbing sense of satisfaction and naturalness in their violent acts.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that the protagonist is "usually" agitated by loud sounds, when the story actually indicates this extreme agitation was unusual or specific to that particular day. The text states "I've always had good hearing but that day, not only was I hearing very well, I was agitated by what I was hearing," suggesting this level of agitation was not typical for the protagonist.

The summary incorrectly characterizes the protagonist's feelings as "disturbing" when the original text explicitly states that killing felt "natural" and "just felt right" to them. The protagonist describes killing the cousin as feeling "even more natural."
The protagonist explicitly mentions not being scared by their actions and instead feeling a sense of rightness, which contradicts describing their feelings as "disturbing."
Using "disturbing" imposes a subjective judgment that isn't present in the original text, as the protagonist actually seems comfortable with their feelings rather than disturbed by them.
rewrites: The protagonist, who has good hearing, experiences an unusually strong reaction to noise while staying at a cousin's house in the forest.
They note a sense of satisfaction and naturalness in their violent acts.

summary: In this disturbing story, the narrator is staying with their cousin in a house located in a forest.
The narrator becomes increasingly agitated by loud noises, particularly a squawking bird outside their window.
Unable to control their anger, the narrator jumps out of the window, catches the bird, and kills it with their bare hands.
Despite the gruesome act, the narrator feels no fear or remorse, instead finding the experience natural and even enjoyable.
Later, while sitting at the table with their cousin, the narrator becomes enraged when the kitchen phone rings.
The cousin yells at the narrator for their unusual behavior, further angering them.
The narrator, who had been harboring resentment towards their cousin for a long time, pounces on him and rips his throat out, finding the act even more satisfying than killing the bird.
The story explores themes of heightened sensory sensitivity, uncontrollable rage, and a disturbing lack of empathy or remorse.
It also suggests that the narrator may have underlying psychological issues or supernatural tendencies that lead to their violent behavior.
explanation: The word "disturbing" is subjective and represents a judgment about the story's content rather than an objective description. Subjective characterizations should be removed from an objective summary.

The word "disturbing" in describing the lack of empathy or remorse is identified as potentially subjective language that should be removed to make the summary fully objective, even though the lack of empathy and remorse itself is objectively presented in the text.

The explanation confirms that the other elements in the sentence (heightened sensory sensitivity, uncontrollable rage, and lack of empathy/remorse) are objectively supported by the text and appropriate to include in the summary.
rewrites: In this story, the narrator is staying with their cousin in a house located in a forest.
The story explores themes of heightened sensory sensitivity, uncontrollable rage, and a lack of empathy or remorse.

summary: One day, the narrator experiences heightened hearing and becomes agitated by loud noises.
They become violent and kill a bird that is making noise outside.
Later, when their cousin yells at them, they also attack and kill their cousin, feeling natural and satisfying about it.
explanation: The word "satisfying" is not explicitly stated in the story and appears to be an interpretation rather than a fact from the text.

While the story does support that the narrator felt it was "natural" to kill their cousin (with the text stating "it felt even more natural to rip my cousin's throat out"), the summary should be revised to be more precise to what's explicitly stated in the text.
rewrites: Later, when their cousin yells at them, they also attack and kill their cousin, feeling that it was even more natural than killing the bird.

summary: The story introduces us to a small street dog fondly named Tomorrow, whose memories reveal a difficult life of cramped cardboard shelters and the haunting loneliness of alleyways.
He has an aversion to uncaring humans who overlook the struggles of the street animals, with the only exception being a gentle and caring girl, The Girl.
The Girl provides Tomorrow with consistent meals, shows tender affection, and promises to see him each day.
This daily routine forms a bond between the two, and Tomorrow returns her kindness with unwavering loyalty and love.
Tragedy hits when The Girl suddenly disappears, leaving Tomorrow alone and desolate in his cardboard shelter.
Despite the icy weather and his uncertain future, the dog finds warmth in the memories of his beloved friend and the fervor of her promises to see him, to see Tomorrow.
explanation: The phrase "fondly named Tomorrow" is a subjective interpretation. The dog in the story believes his name is Tomorrow based on misunderstanding when the girl said "see you tomorrow," not because someone actually named him that.
Describing the dog as having a "difficult life" is a somewhat subjective judgment that isn't directly stated in the story.
"Haunting loneliness" is a subjective emotional characterization that imposes an interpretation rather than stating facts from the story.
The phrase "cramped cardboard shelters" should be revised to match the story's description of a "ramshackle cardboard box."
The phrase "Tragedy hits" uses subjective language that implies an emotional judgment rather than stating objective facts.
The phrase "desolate in his cardboard shelter" contains the subjective term "desolate" which attributes an emotional state to Tomorrow rather than presenting objective information.
rewrites: The story introduces us to a small street dog who believes his name is Tomorrow, whose memories reveal a life in a ramshackle cardboard box in alleyways, separated from most human interaction.
One day The Girl suddenly disappears, leaving Tomorrow alone in his cardboard shelter.

summary: In this poignant story, a small terrier named Tomorrow has been living on the streets for as long as he can remember.
His only solace is a little girl who visits him every day, providing him with food, love, and companionship.
The girl, who remains unnamed, is connected to strange tubes and tanks, hinting at an underlying health condition.
The story follows their routine and the bond they share, with the girl always promising to see Tomorrow the next day.
However, one day, the routine is broken when the girl doesn't show up.
Tomorrow recalls a blaring alarm and a screeching van from the previous day, suggesting that something might have happened to the girl.
As Tomorrow waits for hours, two of the girl's guardians arrive, one in tears and the other shell-shocked, but the girl is nowhere to be seen.

Despite the harsh weather and the unforgiving world around him, Tomorrow finds comfort and warmth in his memories of the girl and the way she said his name, forever determined to meet him, to meet Tomorrow.
explanation: The phrase "poignant story" is subjective and represents a value judgment about the emotional quality of the story. This should be removed or replaced with a more neutral description.
The original sentence uses the word "hinting" which introduces subjectivity, when the summary should be more objective about what the text suggests regarding the girl's condition.

While there is textual evidence supporting the interpretation that the girl has a health condition (mentions of tubes connected to her face, strange tubes and tanks, the dog sensing she was weak, and a possible medical emergency with an alarm and van), the story doesn't explicitly state she has a health condition - this is an inference that should be presented more carefully.
rewrites: In this story, a small terrier named Tomorrow has been living on the streets for as long as he can remember.
The girl, who remains unnamed, is connected to tubes and tanks, suggesting she may have a medical condition.

summary: This is a story about a stray dog named Tomorrow who lives on the streets and has a special bond with a little girl who feeds him.
But one day, the girl doesn't show up and he learns that she has been taken to the hospital.
Despite harsh conditions, Tomorrow waits for her, determined to see her again.
explanation: The dog doesn't "learn" that the girl was taken to a hospital - this is an assumption not supported by the text.
The story only implies an ambulance through "a blaring alarm and a screeching van" but doesn't explicitly state the girl went to a hospital.
While the dog notices the girl's caretakers return without her, the text doesn't indicate the dog understands what happened to the girl or where she went.
rewrites: But one day, the girl doesn't show up, and there are hints of an emergency involving an alarm and a van, possibly an ambulance.

summary: This is an allegorical tale, presenting life events as characters at a party hosted by Life itself.
At the party, Sorrow wore black, Luck sparkled in gold, Worries wore mouse-grey suits, Joy wore yellow, and so on.
Malice and Envy, sat in one corner belittling others, particularly commenting on Love's pink dress and her inability to afford it.
Fame was drunk and encouraged by big Money.
Diligence was helping Power by fetching drinks while Work was busy replenishing the buffet.
When Life gave its speech, he welcomed significant attendees such as Happiness, Love, Sex, Money, and Joy.
After thunderous applause and the start of music, Sex and Eroticism danced a tango while an old lady decided to leave the party.
Wisdom pointed out to Life that he had missed greeting her, an important guest.
Rushing to the lady's side, Life was apologetic, but she responded that she knows all the guests but is often unrecognized.
Only Trouble, Sorrow, Illness, and Death miss her, whom she finds boring.
Life reluctantly agreed, and she handed him her business card before disappearing.

After the party, when all the guests had left, Life read the card which was labeled "Satisfaction - Difficult to reach - Try more often", indicating that satisfaction in life is hard to attain and requires constant effort.
explanation: The summary incorrectly states that "Fame was drunk" when the original text specifically says Fame was "almost drunk" - this is a factual inaccuracy that needs to be corrected to properly represent the story.
The summary omits Eroticism from the list of attendees that Life welcomed in the speech, though this character was specifically mentioned in the original story.
The summary refers to Life as "he" but there's no gender specified for Life in the original text.

While the summary describes the attendees as "significant," which could be considered subjective, this is actually supported by the original text where Life specifically calls them "guests of honor" and singles them out for special welcome.
The summary incorrectly states that Life "reluctantly" agreed, but there is no indication of reluctance in Life's response in the original story.
The original text only shows Life saying "I will miss you" without any description of reluctance before the old lady handed her business card and disappeared.

The phrase "indicating that satisfaction in life is hard to attain and requires constant effort" is an interpretation of the business card's meaning rather than something explicitly stated in the text.
While this interpretation is reasonable and aligns with the allegorical nature of the story, it represents an analysis of the symbolism rather than factual content from the text.
The summary should either remove this interpretive element or clarify that it's an implied meaning to be more objective.
rewrites: Fame was almost drunk and encouraged by big Money.
When Life gave his speech, he welcomed his guests of honor including Happiness, Love, Eroticism, Sex, Money, and Joy.
Life said he would miss her, and she handed him her business card before disappearing.
After the party, when all the guests had left, Life read the card which was labeled "Satisfaction - Difficult to reach - Try more often."

summary: The story revolves around a grand party attended by various personified concepts and emotions, such as Sorrow, Luck, Worries, Joy, Trouble, Malice, Envy, Love, Sex, Eroticism, Illness, Death, Honor, Pride, Kindness, Fame, Money, Power, Fear, Diligence, and Work.
The host of the party is Life, who welcomes his guests of honor, including Happiness, Love, Eroticism, Sex, Money, and Joy.
Throughout the party, the guests interact with one another, displaying their characteristic traits.
Malice and Envy gossip about the other guests, while Sex and Eroticism captivate the crowd with their alluring presence.
Illness and Death share a quiet moment, and Honor struggles to afford cigarettes.
As Life begins his speech, he fails to acknowledge one important guest - an old lady.
Wisdom points out this oversight, and Life rushes to apologize to the old lady, who reveals that she is usually not recognized and that only Trouble, Sorrow, Illness, and Death will miss her.
She hands her business card to Life and leaves the party.
The party continues with various interactions among the guests, and when it ends, Life takes out the old lady's business card, which reads "Satisfaction - Difficult to reach - Try more often."
explanation: The second part of the summary uses subjective language with the word "alluring" to describe Sex and Eroticism's presence, when the story only objectively states that "a murmur went through the crowd" when Sex entered, describes his revealing outfit, Eroticism's reaction, and that their tango dance left "even Malice speechless."
rewrites: Malice and Envy gossip about the other guests, while Sex and Eroticism draw attention from the crowd with their striking presence.

summary: A wide range of personified emotions and characteristics gather at a fancy party thrown by Life.
Some guests are well-received and popular, while others are disliked or ignored.
As the night wears on, the host, Life, forgets to recognize an important guest - Satisfaction - who turns out to be the most valuable of them all.
The party ends and the guests leave, each with their own motives and behaviors.
